text: <@U061HDV96> buy smart wall paint instead of a whiteboard,  or a whiteboard foil.  Can't find the board for an ok price
I thought about it, but I don't think my landlord would be happy.
Perhaps buy a board that happens to be white, paint it and hang it.
Hmm not sure that would work,  you would need whiteboard film for that
Why is it that companies only look for senior developers nowadays?
Depends on their load of projects and company goals.
If you have enough Senior developers to sustain your projects, you can have room for junior ones, or train new ones as they desire.
If they have more projects and need them to be done, it is obvious to higher a senior =. more experience in the domain, much more efficient and fast => more money.

<@U06EANT71>: I agree with <@U086F1Z9U> that the main reason is the efficiency factor. Hiring someone with more experience is worth the extra marginal cost because they are often significantly more efficient and/or already know how to do most of the things you need them to do. 

Another reason that postings across multiple fields bias towards asking for more experience is the assumption that people with less experience may still apply anyway, and then the company can screen based on the candidates they receive, whereas if you post a role for an entry level position it is much less likely senior people with more experience will apply. 

For instance, weâ€™d like to ideally hire a senior android dev with strong experience, but would also probably consider some newer folks for a junior / standard android dev role.
